params.alt: Mindfulness Now at Birmingham Newman University
params.title: Mindfulness Now at Birmingham Newman University

params.text:
You’ve made it to the final week: well done! 

Over the past three weeks, you’ve explored how mindfulness can help with stress, resilience, and self-compassion. This week, we’re focusing on something just as important: how to keep mindfulness going beyond the course. 

Mindfulness isn’t about setting aside time for long meditations (unless you want to!). It’s about finding small, practical ways to bring awareness into everyday life. This week, you’ll explore mindful study techniques, informal mindfulness practices, and a full-length guided meditation to deepen your experience.

Before you begin, take a moment to reflect:

  • Have there been moments when mindfulness has felt helpful in your day-to-day life?
  • What practices have worked best for you so far?

Mindfulness beyond this course

Although this is the final week, mindfulness doesn’t have to stop here. You can revisit the course materials anytime, and all the meditation audios will remain available for you to watch online or download. Whether you continue with short breathing practices or longer meditations, this is just the beginning of making mindfulness your own.

You'll find some suggested resources at the end of the course that could help with your next steps.

As always, there’s no need to do this perfectly. Just explore, experiment, and find what works for you.

params.text:
Introducing the Lake Meditation

The Lake Meditation, adapted from Jon Kabat-Zinn’s work, is a powerful practice that invites us to cultivate stability, stillness, and openness: qualities we can bring into our daily lives.

Imagine a lake. On a clear day, its surface is calm and reflective, mirroring the sky above. When the wind picks up, the surface may become choppy, distorting the reflection, yet beneath the surface, the lake remains undisturbed. In this meditation, you’ll be invited to connect with this imagery. Recognising that, just like the lake, you too can experience moments of stillness, even when life feels turbulent​.

A few things to keep in mind before you begin:
🌀 If you find visualising a lake difficult or uncomfortable, you’re welcome to modify the imagery to something that resonates with you.
💙 There’s no need to force relaxation, simply observe what arises with curiosity and kindness.
🧘‍♂️ You can practice this meditation sitting or lying down, whichever feels best for you.

Take a moment to settle, and when you're ready, press play.

metadata.title: Start with an awareness of breath

params.text:
Pick your Mindfulness plan: create a practice that works for you

Mindfulness isn’t one-size-fits-all. It’s about finding what fits your lifestyle and feels sustainable. Below, you’ll find three levels of mindfulness practice, ranging from minimal to more immersive. 

Have a look at the below plans, and have a think about the level that feels right for you. There's no one perfect way to practice Mindfulness - just choose what feels right for you and adjust as you go.

For those who want to start small, with minimal time commitment

  • One-minute mindful pause – Take a deep breath and check in with how you’re feeling.
  • Mindful moment in daily activities – Choose one routine activity (brushing teeth, making tea, walking) and do it mindfully.
  • 3-minute Breathing Space meditation – Use this short mindfulness practice once a day.
  • Mindful breath check-in before bed – Take five slow breaths before sleeping.

panels.title: 🌱 Level 1: The Minimalist (Mindfulness in Small Doses)

params.text:
For those who want to build a steady habit without a big time commitment

  • 5-10 minutes of formal meditation – Choose a short breathing or body scan practice.
  • Two mindful activities per day – Do one mindful activity from Level 1, plus another (e.g., mindful eating or mindful listening).
  • Pause before reacting – When feeling stressed, use STOP (Stop, Take a breath, Observe, Proceed).
  • Mindful check-in – At the end of the day, note one thing you appreciated or felt grateful for, or take a moment for a few breaths.

panels.title: 🌿 Level 2: The Balanced Approach (A Little Each Day)

params.text:
For those who want to integrate mindfulness more fully into daily life

  • 20-30 minutes of daily meditation – Longer sessions such as the Lake meditation or Mountain meditation.
  • Mindful journaling – Reflect daily on thoughts, emotions, and experiences in a mindfulness journal.
  • Mindful movement – walking meditation or mindful movement for around 10 minutes per day.
  • Pause before reacting – When feeling stressed, use STOP (Stop, Take a breath, Observe, Proceed), or the RAIN meditation.
  • Digital mindfulness – Set intentional screen time breaks, and check in before scrolling mindlessly.
  • Weekly ‘Mindfulness Retreat Moment’ – Dedicate one hour per week to a longer practice, such as a body scan, mindful movement, or sitting meditation.

panels.title: 🌳 Level 3: The Deep Dive (Immersive Mindfulness Practice)

params.text:
The Two Wolves: a Mindfulness perspective

As you explore ways to bring mindfulness into daily life, it's helpful to remember that what we focus on grows. This short story, which you may well have heard before, illustrates how our thoughts and attitudes shape our experience.

Take a moment to listen and reflect. Press play when you're ready.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
The way we spend our time has a powerful impact on our mood, energy, and overall well-being. When we're stressed or overwhelmed, we often neglect the activities that nourish us and focus only on what feels urgent or necessary, sometimes at the cost of our well-being.

This reflection will help you identify what sustains you and what drains you, so you can make more mindful choices about how you use your time. It’s not about eliminating all draining activities (some are unavoidable) but rather about bringing awareness to them and, where possible, adjusting how we approach them.

As well as listening to the audio, you can download the guide below. 
Press play when you're ready.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.title: Sustaining and Draining activities: a guide

params.text:
Ideas for informal Mindfulness practices

Mindfulness isn’t just about sitting in meditation, it’s something you can weave into everyday life. The possibilities are endless. You can bring awareness to anything you do. Below are some ideas to help you explore informal mindfulness practices throughout your day as a student. You don’t have to try them all, just see what sparks your interest and adapt them to fit your routine.

🌅 Waking up mindfully – Before reaching for your phone, take a moment to tune into your senses: the feel of your bedding, the light in your room, the sounds around you. Notice your breath and take a deep inhale before moving into your day.

☕ Mindful morning drink – Whether it’s tea, coffee, or water, take a few moments to fully experience it. Feel the warmth of the cup, the aroma, the taste. No need to rush—just be present.

📖 Savoring the end of meditation – If you do any kind of formal practice in the morning, take an extra moment afterward to notice how you feel. Even if your mind was busy, pause and appreciate the act of slowing down.

🚶‍♀️ Mindful walking – Whether you’re walking across campus or just to your next class, try walking without distractions. Notice the feeling of your feet on the ground, the movement of your legs, the rhythm of your breath. Let yourself fully arrive in the moment.

🎧 Intentional Listening – Instead of always putting in headphones, try walking without them occasionally. Listen to the sounds around you: the rustling of leaves, distant conversations, or birdsong.

🚇 Commuting with awareness – If you take public transport, take a moment to put your phone away and simply notice your surroundings. Feel your breath, check in with your body, or take a moment to reflect on how you’d like to approach the day ahead.

🚲 Biking or driving mindfully – If you drive or bike, take a moment before starting to check in with your breath and posture. Notice any tension in your hands, shoulders, or face, and see if you can soften it as you move.

📚 Arriving before you begin – Before opening your laptop or starting a lecture, pause for a breath. Take a moment to feel settled and focused, setting an intention for your study session.

💻 Screen break awareness – Throughout the day, take a few seconds to step back from your screen. Notice how your eyes feel, roll your shoulders, take a few deep breaths before continuing.

✍️ Writing & reading with presence – Whether you're taking notes or reading, notice your posture, your breath, and the way your mind engages with the material. If you get distracted, gently bring your focus back.

🍎 Eating mindfully – Instead of eating in a rush or while scrolling, try a few mindful bites. Notice the taste, texture, and smell of your food. Even a few seconds of mindful eating can shift your experience.

☀️ Stepping outside – When you take a break, actually take a break. Step away from screens and, if possible, go outside. Even a short moment in fresh air can re-energize your mind.

🎤 Listening with presence – In conversations, practice fully listening rather than just waiting to respond. Notice when your mind wanders and bring your focus back to the person speaking.

🧘‍♂️ Mindful pause between tasks – Before switching to something new, pause for one deep breath. This helps reset your focus rather than rushing through the day on autopilot.

🌙 Mindful reflection on the day – Before bed, take a moment to reflect: What was a small moment of joy or presence today? No need for a long journal entry, just noticing can help you build mindful awareness.

📵 Tech-Free wind down – Try five minutes of screen-free time before bed. Let your mind settle without external input, even if it's just breathing, stretching, or staring out the window.

😌 Noticing transitions to rest – As you get into bed, take a moment to feel the weight of your body sinking into the mattress. Let your breath slow down, allowing yourself to fully arrive in rest.

✨ Final Thought

You don’t need to add extra time to practice mindfulness, it’s about bringing awareness to the things you’re already doing. Pick one or two practices that interest you and see how they feel in your day.

Introducing the sitting meditation

The sitting meditation is a foundational mindfulness practice that invites you to develop a steady, present-moment awareness. Despite its name, you don’t have to be seated. This meditation can be done in any comfortable posture, whether sitting, lying down, or even standing.

At its core, sitting meditation is about bringing attention to the breath and using it as an anchor to the present moment. Thoughts will naturally come and go. That’s completely normal. 

The practice isn’t about stopping thoughts but about noticing them without getting caught up in them.

This session will guide you through mindfulness of breath, body, sounds, thoughts, and feelings, helping you develop an open, non-judgmental awareness. If your mind wanders (which it will!), simply acknowledge it and gently return to the breath.

There’s no need to force relaxation. Just allow yourself to be with your experience as it is. When you're ready, settle into a comfortable position, and press play to begin.

params.text:
Create your own Mindfulness plan

Mindfulness works best when it fits naturally into your daily life. This downloadable, editable document is designed to help you create a mindfulness plan that works for you, whether that means just a few mindful moments a day or a more structured practice.

📝 How to Use This Document:

  • Fill it out digitally – You can download and save this file, and then type directly into the document and update it as your practice evolves.
  • Print and write by hand – If you prefer a paper version, feel free to download and print it out, and fill it in.

params.title: Download and create your mindfulness plan

introPage.introduction:
As this course comes to an end, take a moment to pause and reflect on your experience. Mindfulness isn’t about getting things "right" or reaching a final destination. It’s about noticing, exploring, and finding what works for you.

This self-reflection quiz is a chance to look back at what you've learned, what practices felt helpful, and how you might continue mindfulness in your daily life. There are no right or wrong answers, just your own experience.

Take your time, answer honestly, and see what insights emerge. Press start when you're ready.
introPage.title: Reflecting on your Mindfulness experience

metadata.title: Making mindfulness part of your daily life

params.text:
Building your own home practice routine

Hopefully you've got some ideas from this week about embedding formal and informal mindfulness practice into your daily life. 

Below some further suggestions, including resources that you can explore:

One formal meditation each day is a great habit to build.

Choose the meditation that works best for you: it might be the three-minute breathing space, the body scan or the RAIN meditation. Try out your practice at different times of the day, and find a time that sticks. All the meditations from this course are listed below, so you can download or bookmark them, if you like.

Apps can be a great help here. The NHS-recommended Healthy Minds app can help you build Mindfulness into your daily routine. There are lots of paid options too, like Headspace, though some can be pricey.

Informal mindful practice is about bringing awareness of the present moment to our dairly routine. It's about brining the 'beginner's mind' to what we do, and bringing ourselves our of autopilot.

Some ideas to try out:

🍽 Eating a snack or meal (noticing taste, texture, and smell).
🚶 Walking somewhere (feeling your feet on the ground, noticing your surroundings).
🖊 Writing a text or email (pausing to notice your thoughts before sending).
🪑 Sit somewhere new in a university session, in the cafe, or at home.
🔄 Change your routine: walk a different way, start studying at a different time.
🖊 Use your non-dominant hand for small tasks like brushing your teeth.

Reflective journalling can be a valuable tool in Mindfulness practice. No need to write much, just whatever comes to mind.

It doesn't work for everyone, so don't force yourself. But if it does work for you, keep it up and build it into your daily routine.

🎉 Congratulations on Completing the Course! 🎉

Well done on reaching the end of this four-week mindfulness journey! Taking the time to explore mindfulness, even in small ways, is a real act of self-care and intention. Whether you practiced every day or just dipped in and out, each moment of awareness you’ve cultivated is valuable.

Mindfulness isn’t about sitting perfectly still or meditating perfectly, t’s about building a habit of noticing, pausing, and being present. If you’ve found practices that work for you, I hope you’ll continue to integrate them into daily life in a way that feels natural and supportive.

Remember, you can always revisit the meditations and resources whenever you need them. And if mindfulness has been helpful for you, this is just the beginning, there’s always more to explore. 

 

Finally, if you're willing, please head to the next page to help understand more about how Mindfulness might be useful for university students. It'll only take a few moments!
